metadata.case_name: L. Amar Nath Dogra v. Union of India

facts.text: Public auction on February 25, 1952 at Mandi in Himachal Pradesh for grant of monopoly vend-licence to sell by retail country-liquor for year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953.
Appellant was highest bidder for Rs. 1,28,600/- and bid accepted.
Appellant deposited 1/6 of bid amount, Rs. 21,460/-, within a month.
Appellant started working licence and paid monthly instalments of Rs. 10,714/- each for April and May 1952.
Disputes raised by appellant that Excise authorities defaulted in obligations, e.g., supply of liquor; correspondence ensued; attempts to remedy but appellant not satisfied; appellant stopped sales.
Appellant served notice under section 80 CPC dated September 2, 1952 on Government claiming damages for breach of stipulations.
Collector of Excise directed suspension of appellant's licence under section 36 of Punjab Excise Act, 1914.
Collector proceeded under section 39 of Punjab Excise Act to take over management of vend-shops.
Steps taken for recovery of monthly instalments due from June 1952 as appellant did not pay.

Appellant filed suit No. 345 of 1952 on November 26, 1952 in Sub-Judge Mandi for permanent injunction restraining State from realising balance licence-fees; withdrawn on May 12, 1953 with liberty under O.23 r.1 CPC to file fresh suit.
Fresh suit instituted May 5, 1953 in District Judge, Mandi for damages for breach of contract against Union of India.
District Judge dismissed suit upholding technical objections (no proper s.80 notice, barred under Punjab Land Revenue Act and Excise Act) and findings on merits mostly against appellant.
Appeal to Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh affirmed District Judge on technical objections and merits (reversed one item in appellant's favour).
Certificate under Art.133(1)(b) rejected; special leave obtained from Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was maintainable due to compliance with section 80 CPC, including whether fresh notice required after withdrawal of prior suit, variance between notice and plaint, and whether notice defective.
Whether notice under s.80 CPC provided sufficient details of claims to enable Government to consider and avert suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: There had been substantial compliance with s.80 CPC; single contract breach stated in notice with amount claimed; plaint confined to figure in notice; common items allow relief.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 80 CPC; State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies; Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice stated cause of action (breach of contract) and relief (damages Rs.74,935/8/3).

respondent_arguments.text: Fresh notice under s.80 CPC necessary after withdrawal of prior suit; plaint at variance with notice; notice defective and not according to law.

court_reasoning.text: Compliance with s.80 CPC mandatory; no fresh notice needed if prior notice valid, but here substantial disconformity between plaint and notice: notice lacked details of heads of claim, figures mismatched, new claims post-suspension not in notice; cause of action changed from subsisting contract breaches to termination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice did not inform Government of nature, basis of claims per head to consider/settle; variance complete, no relation between notice claim and plaint items.

court_reasoning.text: Object of s.80 is to give Government notice of proposed suit, facts, reliefs to decide acceptance/resistance; notice must convey substantial information, not pedantically but with common sense.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Details lacking in notice unlike cited precedents where details provided.

court_reasoning.text: Claim for refund of deposit Rs.21,460/- barred by s.40 Punjab Excise Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No compensation or refund on suspension/cancellation under specified sections.

holdings.text: Suit not maintainable for non-compliance with s.80 CPC due to defective notice and variance with plaint; entire claim fails also due to s.40 Punjab Excise Act for deposit refund.
Notice under s.80 must provide sufficient details of claims per head for Government to assess and avert suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of s.80: inform Government of nature of suit, facts, reliefs to consider claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: s.80 terms strictly complied but not pedantically; notice must enable knowledge of claim.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory notice requirement for suits against Government; liberty to file fresh suit after withdrawal.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Excise Act, 1914
statutes_cited.relevance: Suspension of licence; takeover of vend-shops; no refund/compensation on cancellation/suspension.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; lower courts' dismissal of suit for damages upheld solely on ground of non-maintainability due to non-compliance with s.80 CPC; merits not considered.

key_quotes.text: No suit shall be instituted against the Government... until the expiration of two months next after notice in writing has been delivered to... stating the cause of action, the name, description and place of residence of the plaintiff the relief which he claims...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.80 CPC, emphasizing mandatory compliance.

key_quotes.text: The object of section 80 is manifestly to give the Government... sufficient notice for the case which is proposed to be brought against it... so that it... may consider the position and decide... whether the claim... should be accepted or resisted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s.80 from precedent.

key_quotes.text: There is complete variance between the claim made in the notice and the claim in the plaint.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on why notice defective.
